name: SwaggerObject
description: This is the root document object for the API specification. It combines what previously was the Resource Listing and API Declaration (version 1.2 and earlier) together into one document.

properties.name: swagger
properties.desc: Specifies the Swagger Specification version being used. It can be used by the Swagger UI and other clients to interpret the API listing. The value MUST be "2.0".

properties.name: info
properties.desc: Provides metadata about the API. The metadata can be used by the clients if needed.

properties.name: host
properties.desc: The host (name or ip) serving the API. This MUST be the host only and does not include the scheme nor sub-paths. It MAY include a port. If the host is not included, the host serving the documentation is to be used (including the port). The host does not support path templating.

properties.name: basePath
properties.desc: The base path on which the API is served, which is relative to the host. If it is not included, the API is served directly under the host. The value MUST start with a leading slash (/). The basePath does not support path templating.

properties.name: schemes
properties.desc: The transfer protocol of the API. Values MUST be from the list: "http", "https", "ws", "wss". If the schemes is not included, the default scheme to be used is the one used to access the Swagger definition itself.

properties.name: consumes
properties.desc: A list of MIME types the APIs can consume. This is global to all APIs but can be overridden on specific API calls. Value MUST be as described under Mime Types.

properties.name: produces
properties.desc: A list of MIME types the APIs can produce. This is global to all APIs but can be overridden on specific API calls. Value MUST be as described under Mime Types.

properties.name: paths
properties.desc: The available paths and operations for the API.

properties.name: definitions
properties.desc: An object to hold data types produced and consumed by operations.

properties.name: parameters
properties.desc: An object to hold parameters that can be used across operations. This property does not define global parameters for all operations.

properties.name: responses
properties.desc: An object to hold responses that can be used across operations. This property does not define global responses for all operations.

properties.name: securityDefinitions
properties.desc: Security scheme definitions that can be used across the specification.

properties.name: security
properties.desc: A declaration of which security schemes are applied for the API as a whole. The list of values describes alternative security schemes that can be used (that is, there is a logical OR between the security requirements). Individual operations can override this definition.

properties.name: tags
properties.desc: A list of tags used by the specification with additional metadata. The order of the tags can be used to reflect on their order by the parsing tools. Not all tags that are used by the Operation Object must be declared. The tags that are not declared may be organized randomly or based on the tools' logic. Each tag name in the list MUST be unique.

properties.name: externalDocs
properties.desc: Additional external documentation.

name: InfoObject
description: The object provides metadata about the API. The metadata can be used by the clients if needed, and can be presented in the Swagger-UI for convenience.

properties.name: title
properties.desc: The title of the application.

properties.name: description
properties.desc: A short description of the application. GFM syntax can be used for rich text representation.

properties.name: termsOfService
properties.desc: The Terms of Service for the API.

properties.name: contact
properties.desc: The contact information for the exposed API.

properties.name: license
properties.desc: The license information for the exposed API.

properties.name: version
properties.desc: Required Provides the version of the application API (not to be confused with the specification version).

name: ContactObject
description: Contact information for the exposed API.

properties.name: name
properties.desc: The identifying name of the contact person/organization.

properties.name: url
properties.desc: The URL pointing to the contact information. MUST be in the format of a URL.

properties.name: email
properties.desc: The email address of the contact person/organization. MUST be in the format of an email address.

name: LicenseObject
description: License information for the exposed API.

properties.name: name
properties.desc: The license name used for the API.

properties.name: url
properties.desc: A URL to the license used for the API. MUST be in the format of a URL.

name: PathsObject
description: Holds the relative paths to the individual endpoints. The path is appended to the basePath in order to construct the full URL. The Paths may be empty, due to ACL constraints.

properties.name: [key: string]
properties.desc: A relative path to an individual endpoint. The field name MUST begin with a slash. The path is appended to the basePath in order to construct the full URL. Path templating is allowed.

name: PathItemObject
description: Describes the operations available on a single path. A Path Item may be empty, due to ACL constraints. The path itself is still exposed to the documentation viewer but they will not know which operations and parameters are available.

properties.name: $ref
properties.desc: Allows for an external definition of this path item. The referenced structure MUST be in the format of a Path Item Object. If there are conflicts between the referenced definition and this Path Item's definition, the behavior is undefined.

properties.name: get
properties.desc: A definition of a GET operation on this path.

properties.name: put
properties.desc: A definition of a PUT operation on this path.

properties.name: post
properties.desc: A definition of a POST operation on this path.

properties.name: delete
properties.desc: A definition of a DELETE operation on this path.

properties.name: options
properties.desc: A definition of a OPTIONS operation on this path.

properties.name: head
properties.desc: A definition of a HEAD operation on this path.

properties.name: patch
properties.desc: A definition of a PATCH operation on this path.

properties.name: parameters
properties.desc: A list of parameters that are applicable for all the operations described under this path. These parameters can be overridden at the operation level, but cannot be removed there. The list MUST NOT include duplicated parameters. A unique parameter is defined by a combination of a name and location. The list can use the Reference Object to link to parameters that are defined at the Swagger Object's parameters. There can be one "body" parameter at most.

name: OperationObject
description: Describes a single API operation on a path.

properties.name: tags
properties.desc: A list of tags for API documentation control. Tags can be used for logical grouping of operations by resources or any other qualifier.

properties.name: summary
properties.desc: A short summary of what the operation does. For maximum readability in the swagger-ui, this field SHOULD be less than 120 characters.

properties.name: description
properties.desc: A verbose explanation of the operation behavior. GFM syntax can be used for rich text representation.

properties.name: externalDocs
properties.desc: Additional external documentation for this operation.

properties.name: operationId
properties.desc: Unique string used to identify the operation. The id MUST be unique among all operations described in the API. Tools and libraries MAY use the operationId to uniquely identify an operation, therefore, it is recommended to follow common programming naming conventions.

properties.name: consumes
properties.desc: A list of MIME types the operation can consume. This overrides the consumes definition at the Swagger Object. An empty value MAY be used to clear the global definition. Value MUST be as described under Mime Types.

properties.name: produces
properties.desc: A list of MIME types the operation can produce. This overrides the produces definition at the Swagger Object. An empty value MAY be used to clear the global definition. Value MUST be as described under Mime Types.

properties.name: parameters
properties.desc: A list of parameters that are applicable for this operation. If a parameter is already defined at the Path Item, the new definition will override it, but can never remove it. The list MUST NOT include duplicated parameters. A unique parameter is defined by a combination of a name and location. The list can use the Reference Object to link to parameters that are defined at the Swagger Object's parameters. There can be one "body" parameter at most.

properties.name: responses
properties.desc: The list of possible responses as they are returned from executing this operation.

properties.name: schemes
properties.desc: The transfer protocol for the operation. Values MUST be from the list: "http", "https", "ws", "wss". The value overrides the Swagger Object schemes definition.

properties.name: deprecated
properties.desc: Declares this operation to be deprecated. Usage of the declared operation should be refrained. Default value is false.

properties.name: security
properties.desc: A declaration of which security schemes are applied for this operation. The list of values describes alternative security schemes that can be used (that is, there is a logical OR between the security requirements). This definition overrides any declared top-level security. To remove a top-level security declaration, an empty array can be used.

name: ExternalDocumentationObject
description: Allows referencing an external resource for extended documentation.

properties.name: description
properties.desc: A short description of the target documentation. GFM syntax can be used for rich text representation.

properties.name: url
properties.desc: The URL for the target documentation. Value MUST be in the format of a URL.

name: ParameterObject
description: Describes a single operation parameter.

properties.name: name
properties.desc:
The name of the parameter. Parameter names are case sensitive.
  • If in is "path", the name field MUST correspond to the associated path segment from the path field in the Paths Object. See Path Templating for further information.
  • For all other cases, the name corresponds to the parameter name used based on the in property.

properties.name: in
properties.desc: The location of the parameter. Possible values are "query", "header", "path", "formData" or "body".

properties.name: description
properties.desc: A brief description of the parameter. This could contain examples of use. GFM syntax can be used for rich text representation.

properties.name: required
properties.desc: Determines whether this parameter is mandatory. If the parameter is in "path", this property is required and its value MUST be true. Otherwise, the property MAY be included and its default value is false.

properties.name: schema
properties.desc: The schema defining the type used for the body parameter.

properties.name: type
properties.desc: The type of the parameter. Since the parameter is not located at the request body, it is limited to simple types (that is, not an object). The value MUST be one of "string", "number", "integer", "boolean", "array" or "file". If type is "file", the consumes MUST be either "multipart/form-data", " application/x-www-form-urlencoded" or both and the parameter MUST be in "formData".

properties.name: format
properties.desc: The extending format for the previously mentioned type. See Data Type Formats for further details.

Sets the ability to pass empty-valued parameters. This is valid only for either query or formData parameters and allows you to send a parameter with a name only or an empty value. Default value is false.

properties.name: items
properties.desc: Required if type is "array". Describes the type of items in the array.

properties.name: collectionFormat
properties.desc:
Determines the format of the array if type array is used. Possible values are:
  • csv - comma separated values foo,bar.
  • ssv - space separated values foo bar.
  • tsv - tab separated values foo\tbar.
  • pipes - pipe separated values foo|bar.
  • multi - corresponds to multiple parameter instances instead of multiple values for a single instance foo=bar&foo=baz. This is valid only for parameters in "query" or "formData".
Default value is csv.

properties.name: default
properties.desc: Declares the value of the parameter that the server will use if none is provided, for example a "count" to control the number of results per page might default to 100 if not supplied by the client in the request. (Note: "default" has no meaning for required parameters.) See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-6.2. Unlike JSON Schema this value MUST conform to the defined type for this parameter.

properties.name: maximum
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.1.2.

properties.name: exclusiveMaximum
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.1.2.

properties.name: minimum
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.1.3.

properties.name: exclusiveMinimum
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.1.3.

properties.name: maxLength
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.2.1.

properties.name: minLength
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.2.2.

properties.name: pattern
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.2.3.

properties.name: maxItems
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.3.2.

properties.name: minItems
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.3.3.

properties.name: uniqueItems
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.3.4.

properties.name: enum
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.5.1.

properties.name: multipleOf
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.1.1.

name: ItemsObject
description: A limited subset of JSON-Schema's items object. It is used by parameter definitions that are not located in "body".

properties.name: type
properties.desc: The internal type of the array. The value MUST be one of "string", "number", "integer", "boolean", or "array". Files and models are not allowed.

properties.name: format
properties.desc: The extending format for the previously mentioned type. See Data Type Formats for further details.

properties.name: items
properties.desc: Required if type is "array". Describes the type of items in the array.

properties.name: collectionFormat
properties.desc:
Determines the format of the array if type array is used. Possible values are:
  • csv - comma separated values foo,bar.
  • ssv - space separated values foo bar.
  • tsv - tab separated values foo\tbar.
  • pipes - pipe separated values foo|bar.
Default value is csv.

properties.name: default
properties.desc: Declares the value of the item that the server will use if none is provided. (Note: "default" has no meaning for required items.) See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-6.2. Unlike JSON Schema this value MUST conform to the defined type for the data type.

properties.name: maximum
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.1.2.

properties.name: exclusiveMaximum
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.1.2.

properties.name: minimum
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.1.3.

properties.name: exclusiveMinimum
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.1.3.

properties.name: maxLength
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.2.1.

properties.name: minLength
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.2.2.

properties.name: pattern
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.2.3.

properties.name: maxItems
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.3.2.

properties.name: minItems
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.3.3.

properties.name: uniqueItems
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.3.4.

properties.name: enum
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.5.1.

properties.name: multipleOf
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.1.1.

name: ResponsesObject
description: A container for the expected responses of an operation. The container maps a HTTP response code to the expected response. It is not expected from the documentation to necessarily cover all possible HTTP response codes, since they may not be known in advance. However, it is expected from the documentation to cover a successful operation response and any known errors.

properties.name: default
properties.desc: The documentation of responses other than the ones declared for specific HTTP response codes. It can be used to cover undeclared responses. Reference Object can be used to link to a response that is defined at the Swagger Object's responses section.

properties.name: [key: string]
properties.desc: Any HTTP status code can be used as the property name (one property per HTTP status code). Describes the expected response for that HTTP status code. Reference Object can be used to link to a response that is defined at the Swagger Object's responses section.

name: ResponseObject
description: Describes a single response from an API Operation.

properties.name: description
properties.desc: A short description of the response. GFM syntax can be used for rich text representation.

properties.name: schema
properties.desc: A definition of the response structure. It can be a primitive, an array or an object. If this field does not exist, it means no content is returned as part of the response. As an extension to the Schema Object, its root type value may also be "file". This SHOULD be accompanied by a relevant produces mime-type.

properties.name: headers
properties.desc: A list of headers that are sent with the response.

properties.name: examples
properties.desc: An example of the response message.

name: HeadersObject
description: Lists the headers that can be sent as part of a response.

properties.name: [key: string]
properties.desc: The name of the property corresponds to the name of the header. The value describes the type of the header.

name: ExampleObject
description: Allows sharing examples for operation responses.

properties.name: [key: string]
properties.desc: The name of the property MUST be one of the Operation produces values (either implicit or inherited). The value SHOULD be an example of what such a response would look like.

name: HeaderObject
description: A simple header with of an integer type:

properties.name: description
properties.desc: A short description of the header.

properties.name: type
properties.desc: The type of the object. The value MUST be one of "string", "number", "integer", "boolean", or "array".

properties.name: format
properties.desc: The extending format for the previously mentioned type. See Data Type Formats for further details.

properties.name: items
properties.desc: Required if type is "array". Describes the type of items in the array.

properties.name: collectionFormat
properties.desc:
Determines the format of the array if type array is used. Possible values are:
  • csv - comma separated values foo,bar.
  • ssv - space separated values foo bar.
  • tsv - tab separated values foo\tbar.
  • pipes - pipe separated values foo|bar.
Default value is csv.

properties.name: default
properties.desc: Declares the value of the header that the server will use if none is provided. (Note: "default" has no meaning for required headers.) See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-6.2. Unlike JSON Schema this value MUST conform to the defined type for the header.

properties.name: maximum
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.1.2.

properties.name: exclusiveMaximum
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.1.2.

properties.name: minimum
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.1.3.

properties.name: exclusiveMinimum
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.1.3.

properties.name: maxLength
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.2.1.

properties.name: minLength
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.2.2.

properties.name: pattern
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.2.3.

properties.name: maxItems
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.3.2.

properties.name: minItems
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.3.3.

properties.name: uniqueItems
properties.desc: https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.3.4.

properties.name: enum
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.5.1.

properties.name: multipleOf
properties.desc: See https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-fge-json-schema-validation-00#section-5.1.1.

name: TagObject
description: Allows adding meta data to a single tag that is used by the Operation Object. It is not mandatory to have a Tag Object per tag used there.

properties.name: name
properties.desc: The name of the tag.

properties.name: description
properties.desc: A short description for the tag. GFM syntax can be used for rich text representation.

properties.name: externalDocs
properties.desc: Additional external documentation for this tag.

name: ReferenceObject
description: A simple object to allow referencing other definitions in the specification. It can be used to reference parameters and responses that are defined at the top level for reuse.

properties.name: $ref
properties.desc: The reference string.

name: SchemaObject
description: The Schema Object allows the definition of input and output data types. These types can be objects, but also primitives and arrays. This object is based on the JSON Schema Specification Draft 4 and uses a predefined subset of it. On top of this subset, there are extensions provided by this specification to allow for more complete documentation.

properties.name: discriminator
properties.desc: Adds support for polymorphism. The discriminator is the schema property name that is used to differentiate between other schema that inherit this schema. The property name used MUST be defined at this schema and it MUST be in the required property list. When used, the value MUST be the name of this schema or any schema that inherits it.

properties.name: readOnly
properties.desc: Relevant only for Schema "properties" definitions. Declares the property as "read only". This means that it MAY be sent as part of a response but MUST NOT be sent as part of the request. Properties marked as readOnly being true SHOULD NOT be in the required list of the defined schema. Default value is false.

properties.name: xml
properties.desc: This MAY be used only on properties schemas. It has no effect on root schemas. Adds Additional metadata to describe the XML representation format of this property.

properties.name: externalDocs
properties.desc: Additional external documentation for this schema.

properties.name: example
properties.desc: A free-form property to include an example of an instance for this schema.

name: XMLObject
description: A metadata object that allows for more fine-tuned XML model definitions.

properties.name: name
properties.desc: Replaces the name of the element/attribute used for the described schema property. When defined within the Items Object (items), it will affect the name of the individual XML elements within the list. When defined alongside type being array (outside the items), it will affect the wrapping element and only if wrapped is true. If wrapped is false, it will be ignored.

properties.name: namespace
properties.desc: The URL of the namespace definition. Value SHOULD be in the form of a URL.

properties.name: prefix
properties.desc: The prefix to be used for the name.

properties.name: attribute
properties.desc: Declares whether the property definition translates to an attribute instead of an element. Default value is false.

properties.name: wrapped
properties.desc: MAY be used only for an array definition. Signifies whether the array is wrapped (for example, <books><book/><book/></books>) or unwrapped (<book/><book/>). Default value is false. The definition takes effect only when defined alongside type being array (outside the items).

name: DefinitionsObject
description: An object to hold data types that can be consumed and produced by operations. These data types can be primitives, arrays or models.

properties.name: [key: string]
properties.desc: A single definition, mapping a "name" to the schema it defines.

name: ParametersDefinitionsObject
description: An object to hold parameters to be reused across operations. Parameter definitions can be referenced to the ones defined here.

properties.name: [key: string]
properties.desc: A single parameter definition, mapping a "name" to the parameter it defines.

name: ResponsesDefinitionsObject
description: An object to hold responses to be reused across operations. Response definitions can be referenced to the ones defined here.

properties.name: [key: string]
properties.desc: A single response definition, mapping a "name" to the response it defines.

name: SecurityDefinitionsObject
description: A declaration of the security schemes available to be used in the specification. This does not enforce the security schemes on the operations and only serves to provide the relevant details for each scheme.

properties.name: [key: string]
properties.desc: A single security scheme definition, mapping a "name" to the scheme it defines.

name: SecuritySchemeObject
description: Allows the definition of a security scheme that can be used by the operations. Supported schemes are basic authentication, an API key (either as a header or as a query parameter) and OAuth2's common flows (implicit, password, application and access code).

properties.name: type
properties.desc: Any

properties.name: description
properties.desc: Any

properties.name: name
properties.desc: apiKey

properties.name: in
properties.desc: apiKey

properties.name: flow
properties.desc: oauth2

properties.name: authorizationUrl
properties.desc: oauth2 ("implicit", "accessCode")

properties.name: tokenUrl
properties.desc: oauth2 ("password", "application", "accessCode")

properties.name: scopes
properties.desc: oauth2

name: ScopesObject
description: Lists the available scopes for an OAuth2 security scheme.

properties.name: [key: string]
properties.desc: Maps between a name of a scope to a short description of it (as the value of the property).

name: SecurityRequirementObject
description: Lists the required security schemes to execute this operation. The object can have multiple security schemes declared in it which are all required (that is, there is a logical AND between the schemes).

properties.name: [key: string]
properties.desc: Each name must correspond to a security scheme which is declared in the Security Definitions. If the security scheme is of type "oauth2", then the value is a list of scope names required for the execution. For other security scheme types, the array MUST be empty.
